title: Brexit deal faces familiar obstacle — Northern Ireland unionists
text:
DUP leader Arlene Foster in Manchester | Ben Stansall/AFP via Getty Images BREXIT FILES INSIGHT Brexit deal faces familiar obstacle — Northern Ireland unionists Without Democratic Unionist Party votes, it is hard to see how Boris Johnson’s deal can pass the House of Commons.

It all looks eerily familiar: A deal has been done, but the British prime minister is facing resistance from his own allies.

Boris Johnson's government may have agreed a deal with Brussels but he now faces the same problem Theresa May did: The Democratic Unionist Party, the Conservative government’s confidence-and-supply partner, is digging its heels in and refusing to back the deal. At lunchtime, it put out a statement saying the deal “drives a coach and horses through the professed sanctity of the Belfast Agreement” and “would not be in Northern Ireland’s long term interests.”

There are more opposition MPs than ever before in this parliament who support a negotiated exit agreement with the EU. Getting their support as well as the DUP’s is important if Johnson is to get his deal over the line (he is currently 45 MPs short of a majority). Not only that, the Northern Irish party's backing is the key to unlocking votes from Brexiteer MPs within the Tory Party.

In recent months, this fact has forced many in Westminster to grapple with some of the hard realities of Northern Irish politics, which they could hitherto ignore. Fundamentally, it’s about identity, said Matthew O’Toole, former No. 10 spokesman on Europe under both David Cameron and Theresa May. “It was always going to be difficult for the DUP to do this. Fundamentally it is really about being as British as possible” — and that means no divergence between Northern Ireland and the U.K. mainland.

The DUP is keen to cut its losses by shoring up its core vote and fighting to retain as many constituencies as possible.

“There’s always been people overestimating the capacity of the DUP to accept very much differentiation at all between Northern Ireland and Great Britain,” O’Toole added. “They’ve said themselves they are fundamentally a unionist party: They couldn’t acquiesce voluntarily to anything that even holds up the possibility of divergence, economically, and politically. This deal certainly from their perspective does that.”

There’s also an electoral calculation. “If there’s any kind of election coming up they can’t be seen to go along with this,” O’Toole said. The DUP’s voter base is made up largely of people who back its hard-line stance on the union of the United Kingdom. Electorally, the party is on the back foot: In an upcoming election, it is almost certain to lose the liberal university constituency of South Belfast, and is at risk of losing at least two more seats — including their Westminster leader Nigel Dodds’. The DUP is keen to cut its losses by shoring up its core vote and fighting to retain as many constituencies as possible.

The DUP may also be taking advantage of its influence while it can. Andrew McQuillan, who works for public affairs company Edelman and closely follows Northern Irish affairs, said the era of its dominance is coming to an end. “The tectonic plates in Northern Ireland are shifting,” he said. “There’s every chance that there will soon be more Catholics than Protestants [in Northern Ireland] and the recent European and council elections have shown that there’s a lot of people who no longer want to box themselves in as nationalists and unionists.”

For his part, Johnson may have calculated that he will have to face the consequences of going ahead without the DUP — if his deal falls in parliament, he must ask the EU for an extension. If the EU refuses, MPs face the choice of Johnson's deal or no deal. Should they decide to give the U.K. more time, Johnson is likely to face a confidence vote.

But in such a scenario, he would head into an election — whenever it comes — able to blame everyone but himself for stalling Brexit.
